results.title: The Lake district
results.creator_credit: Edgar H. Anstey, British Transport Films and Alex Strasser
results.brief_description: The English Lake District, an unspoiled region of mountains and lakes in the north-west of England. Now a national park where climbing, walking, sailing, and fishing may be enjoyed, and pilgrims may pay homage to Wordsworth and the district which inspired him. Narrated by Michael Redgrave.

results.title: The Ladybird story
results.creator_credit: Pat Dowling and Pat Dowling Pictures
results.brief_description: The discovery of the Vedalia ladybird beetle in Australia, in 1885; how it benefits humans in controlling harmful pests; exported to America where an entire industry was threatened by the cottony-cushion scale. Life cycle of scale and beetle shown in closeup.

results.title: The Lady Eve [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Paul Jones, Paramount Pictures and Preston Sturges
results.brief_description: Henry Fonda is a millionaire scientist who is obsessed by snakes. Barbara Stanwyck is the fearless gambler and hustler whose only phobia is reptiles. When they meet on an ocean liner in Latin America, the scene is set for one of Hollywood’s classiest, most electric and funniest of romantic screwball comedies. The dour serious Fonda is a delightful foil to Stanwyck’s vivacious smart-talking Eve. William Demarest plays Fonda’s cynical wary man-servant who does his best to keep Eve away from the innocent Fonda. But Eve has lots of tricks up her sleeve. The effortless charm of this movie is a testament to the wry comic talents of Preston Sturges. Whereas Ernst Lubitsch’s legacy to romantic comedy was a highly stylised European elegance, Sturges took Lubitsch’s blue-print and invested it with American physicality and vigor. The eroticism of the charge between Stanwyck and Fonda is earthy and tangible. The fast script is full of great one-liners, the costumes by Edith Head are delightful, and the supporting cast include some of Hollywood’s finest comic character actors. Watch out for the excellent animated title sequence at the beginning of the movie.

results.title: The Kremlin
results.brief_description: A guided tour of the Kremlin recreating events in Russian history associated with the building from the 12th century up until its present day role as a museum and seat of the Social Government. Shows the great halls, paintings, ikons and treasures which belonged to the Czars.

results.title: The Koorie Oral History Program and the Bill Onus family archive
results.brief_description: Koorie people record ourselves as a means of self-representation, to destroy stereotypes and to ensure that we are not erased. These films from the Koori Oral History Program and the Bill Onus family archive preserve our culture and kinship for future generations.

constellations_primary.name: Connecting through film
constellations_primary.description: Film acts like a time capsule to our collective past. Capturing our most treasured moments with family has never been more accessible, with technology right at our fingers.

results.title_for_label: The Koorie Oral History Program and the Bill Onus family archive
results.description:
Koorie people record ourselves as a means of self-representation, to destroy stereotypes and to ensure that we are not erased. These films from the Koorie Oral History Program and the Bill Onus family archive preserve our culture and kinship for future generations.

“When we talk about Traditional Aboriginal knowledge in Victoria we need to remember it is one of the oldest living forms of communication in the world. It continues today as one of the main mediums through which cultural knowledge and story lines are passed on. The images you will see in this exhibition reflect the value and importance of oral knowledge as an ongoing and vibrant cultural link with the past.” - Dr Wayne Atkinson senior Yorta Yorta Elder and creator of the Koorie Oral History Program
description_for_label:
Koorie people record ourselves as a means of self-representation, to destroy stereotypes and to ensure that we are not erased. These films from the Koorie Oral History Program and the Bill Onus family archive preserve our culture and kinship for future generations.

The images you will see in this exhibition reflect the value and importance of oral knowledge as an ongoing and vibrant cultural link with the past.” - Dr Wayne Atkinson senior Yorta Yorta Elder and creator of the Koorie Oral History Program

results.title: The Knowledge of healing
results.creator_credit: Marcel Hoehn, T&C Film AG and Franz Reichle
results.brief_description: The Knowledge of Healing is the first feature length documentary dealing with Tibetan medicine. Originally recorded in Gyushi, “The Knowledge of Healing” is a medical manual written in the 12th century. Its text describes one of the most highly developed, holistic approaches to medicine, comprising its own pharmacopoeia of herbs, roots and minerals. The film explains the text through case studies of patients progressing under treatment for ailments and conditions deemed incurable in the West. The film also contains interviews with two leading Tibetan physicians as well as H.H. The Dalai Lama. In Tibetan, Russian, German and Buryat with English subtitles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Marcel Hoehn, T&C Film AG and Franz Reichle

results.title: The King who loved his family
results.brief_description: A film of historical interest showing many of the less well known photographs of events in the life of the late King George VI. Made on the occassion of his death, the film is a tribute to a man and his family. Includes the funeral procession of King George’s grandfather; the ‘Spreading Chestnut Tree’ game in which the King participated at a holiday camp; the King yachting with his father; the visit to Australia; shipboard games en route to South Africa; an early visit to France; extracts from the abdication speech of King Edward.
